I see from this that he is somewhat inclined to support the use of Ottoman models for codification of at least part of the law in Bahrain; and you will remember that I told you that the Political Resident is most insistent that Bahrain should use Indian (or Sudan) rather than Ottoman models. 3. Will you please refer to correspondence ending with Weightman's demi-official letter No. C/346 dated the 23rd April 1940 regarding Judge Lloyd ? 2. I have been discussing the matter with Belgrave and I understand that Judge Lloyd is now serving with the Intelli gence Department in Iraq and will presumably not be available for Bahrain. It occurred to me that there is a remote possi bility of the Aden Government having someone either British, Indian or Arab with a good knowledge of law whom they could lend to us for the purpose of framing some simple codes of procedure for the guidance of the Bahrain Courts. Such a man would know Arabic and would also be familiar with the Indian Codes, which would be a great help as people who are accustomed to other systems have a tendency to try and introduce them. If this suggestion is not good, then there only remain Arab countries such as Palestine, Egypt and the Sudan and in these countries other systems of law prevail. 3. I am inclined to think that a really good Indian might perhaps be the best solution after all. Moat Indians have studied Arabic as a classical language in college and University and should not have such great difficulty in acquiring a sufficient knowledge of the language to carry on their work in Bahrain. 4. In addition to framing Civil codes of procedure, he would also be required to alter the Sudan Penal Code so as to make it suitable for Bahrain. Dear Alban, With reference to your D.O.No. G/67 r 6-4:/4: dated 28th June, 1941, enquiring about the Sudan Civil Code and Procedure. I understand that he has been ill.4/17 @ Syed Said bin Syed Khalaf accompanied by Mohsin bin Ahmed A1 Tajir called to see me on the 30th September. During the course of a long conversation they complained that there v/as no codified lav; in Bahrain with the result that the decisions of the local judges, whose knowledge of 'k*A*f*> affairs is at the best of times small, were quite unpredictable. They further stated that the Bahama community was not sufficiently well represented in Bahrain Government appointments. They maintained that whereas the Bahamas formed the largest community they held practically none of the minor Government appoint- -ments and as far as the Customs was concerned there was only one clerk from the community. Syed Said bin Syed Khalaf said that the present condition of the Bahama was infinitely better than it had been in the past and that for that they were very grateful to the Adviser and to the British representatives. He recalled the day when the A1 Khalifah divided the Bahama man, woman, child, property, and gardens entirely as they liked anong the members of the family and when the property of no Bahama was safe in the streets of Manama. With regard to the codified law I said that I wil-±- talk to the Adviser and pointed out that we are endeavour ing to have one of the junior members of the Al Khalifah family trained in legal affairs in Palestine. With regard to the small number of Bahama at presort holding Government appointments I said I thought that it was probably due to their not beeing sufficiently educated to make their employment profitable. At the present time we were all of us looking for clerks and I could not under -stand why anyone who could type could fail to get an appointment. It later transpired that Haji Mohsin bin Ahmed Al Tajir was looking for an appointment tax. in the Agency for his son Mohamed. 2-10-44

mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence between British officials regarding efforts to implement a codification of law in Bahrain. The correspondence is primarily between Charles Belgrave, Adviser to the Government of Bahrain; Major Reginald George Evelin Alban, Political Agent in Bahrain; and Lieutenant-Colonel Charles Geoffrey Prior, Political Resident in the Persian Gulf.The correspondence discusses possible models that could be used as a template for Bahrain (such as the Penal Code of Sudan). Also discussed is from where an individual with the necessary skills needed to draft Bahrain's legal code could be hired; suggestions made include India, Yemen and Zanzibar.The file contains a letter to Belgrave from Judge H I Lloyd regarding his potential involvement in the drafting of Bahrain's legal code and a possible visit to Bahrain (ff 5-6).
